content.title: Coffee Waste Management: Challenges and Opportunities for Regenerative Solutions
content.excerpt: Examination of coffee waste management problems, environmental impacts, and opportunities to transform waste into wealth within regenerative agriculture frameworks.
keyPoints: Wet processing methods use 5-15 liters of water per kg of coffee
Waste contains toxic substances including caffeine, tannins, and polyphenols
Causes severe water pollution, soil degradation, and health risks

content.title: Building Agency for Disadvantaged Communities in Wanja Kerssa
content.excerpt: Report from the second Food System Innovation Platform (FSIP) Workshop focused on advancing collective understanding and strengthening collaboration around food system transformation.
keyPoints: Only 10% of women and 11% of children had adequate nutrition

content.title: Stakeholders Workshop on Regenerative Action Plan for Coffee Waste Management
content.excerpt: Workshop convened to validate challenges and opportunities identified by the Wanja Kerssa community and jointly develop an action plan for addressing coffee processing waste.
keyPoints: 40 processing plants closed due to lagoon-related issues
Farmers shifting from wet to dry processing due to health hazards
Cooperative processors contribute more pollution than private enterprises
